metadata.subject: Crime Victims' Rights During Criminal Investigations: Applying the Crime Victims' Rights Act Before Criminal Charges Are Filed

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida

relationships.description: Epstein sexually abused Jane Doe Number One
Epstein sexually abused Jane Doe Number Two
DOJ investigated and negotiated non-prosecution agreement with Epstein
Kyl criticized Holder/DOJ's interpretation of CVRA

analysis.purpose: To argue for the application of Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) rights during criminal investigations before formal charges are filed
analysis.significance: Challenges DOJ's narrow interpretation of CVRA and uses Epstein case to illustrate importance of victim rights in pre-charging phase

concerns: DOJ interpretation limiting CVRA rights to post-charging phase
Potential violations of victims' rights in Epstein case

notable_quotes: If crime victims have no rights during criminal investigations, then many crime victims will never have any rights at all.
The Government argued it was not required to confer in any way with the victims, or even treat them fairly, because the CVRA was not yet in play.

CVRA rights attach when federal law enforcement or prosecuting agencies have identified a federal crime and a particular victim with sufficient precision that they would send a 'target' letter to a criminal defendant in similar circumstances.
red_flags: DOJ's narrow interpretation of CVRA limits victim participation
Epstein non-prosecution agreement made without victim consultation
Potential secondary victimization of crime victims

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion in this legal analysis document

illegal_activity.description: This is a legal analysis article discussing victims' rights, not evidence of illegal activity

public_knowledge.context: This law review article discusses publicly known Epstein case and CVRA legal interpretation issues

analysis.summary: This legal article argues that the Crime Victims' Rights Act should apply during criminal investigations before formal charges are filed, using the Jeffrey Epstein case as a key example where victims were excluded from plea negotiations. The authors critique the Department of Justice's narrow interpretation of CVRA rights and propose a framework for when victims' rights should attach during investigations.
